We also have a very robust cover proforma, with model text. We use Oak lessons followed by booklet work, so the "no frills" cover lesson can be prepared pretty quickly.
 /end

2/ we also fix the roof while the sun is shining. Making sure your students are well equipped each lesson, always bring their booklets and your seating plan is up to date saves you a lot of stress at 0650 on a Thursday when you're running a temperature and vomiting everywhere

Glad to head a department where teachers would be in the 13%. If staff are ill, they let me know where they are up to, that's all. I set the cover, they go back to bed. Mad to do it any other way.

(most of the FOF is peer assessed. There will be a few questions in each that the teacher will check. Takes around five minutes to do a class set. Same applies for regular Carousel homeworks - one quiz a week, five minutes per class to "mark" normally)

This is our department's feedback policy if anyone is interested, but the very fact that people are like "what do you do instead" is worrying. Marking is a NOTHING, it's like saying "oh you don't begin your class with a ritual dance, what do you do instead?" https://t.co/P8K6VgKPjP

Senior leaders: find a better way. 

It is *not* a necessary part of teachers' jobs to mark books.

It *is* a necessary part of leaders' jobs to protect their teachers, lower their workload, support them, help them and get the best out of them. 

Find a better way.

/end
If you are a senior leader, and you are *still* enforcing a rigorous marking regime, take a good look in the mirror. You don't need to do this. There is no evidence to support it. >

The difference it's made to my workload and wellbeing is off the charts. It's also a big green flag for

A school that cares about my wellbeing

A school that respects my professional autonomy

A school that is happy to cut the crap

I haven't marked a student's book in over three years.

I haven't written a comment in a student's book in over three years. 

I haven't taken students' books home with me in over three years.

In all that time, not a single student has complained. And I flipping love my school.

(PS those giants are basically @Doug_Lemov and @tombennett71, and @LeeDonaghy is the one who started me off on the way of thinking I outline in the blogs/videos/articles above)

Anyway, I've collated everything I know about behaviour here. I have tried to keep it

1. Concrete
2. Time efficient
3. Helpful
4. Possible

https://t.co/FiEHPzQLbA

I stand on the shoulders of giants. Hope it helps.

hard about what I see, about how action leads to consequence, and about how we can do better next time. I don't consider myself an expert. 

Importantly, I also still struggle with behaviour. I live it every day, and know deeply the accompanying feelings of shame and inadequacy.

By what authority do I so arrogantly condemn the types of advice offered above? I guess not a lot. Mostly experience, and a ton of reading and observing. I am lucky to be well supported, and I'm lucky to have benefitted from others' wisdom. I support a *lot* of staff and think

I imagine there are some people who will say "but I did this and it worked", ok so first you may be the 1%, secondly there are probably a bunch of other things going on that you didn't notice. I've seen them fail too many times to let comments like that slide. https://t.co/WReYHCQTCS

Things which are impossible:

Remember it isn't personal
Keep your head up
Don't rise to it
Don't be ashamed

Things like "it isn't personal" might be true in an absolute sense, but assuming someone will just be like "omg you're so right my problems are solved" is pretty naive

Some people have philosophical problems with what I've just said - the idea of externally imposed authority. Cool, I'm ok with that. But don't pretend like your way makes teaching easier, even if you find it more ethical (which I don't btw).

Co-constructing some kind of rule system with the students fits into this as well. When you give students authority over what the rules are, you are literally undermining yourself and your own authority.

Things which are ordinarily actively damaging:

Moving the naughty students to the back
Rewarding students who are doing the right thing (they are supposed to do the right thing)
Giving the naughty students responsibility 
Whole class rewards
Whole class sanctions

There's also the old classic "spend time with them in the playground"

What jokes. The idea that this would help your behaviour in class is for the birds. Protip: it doesn't work. Go to the staffroom and have lunch with colleagues instead. Much better.

Things which are probably a waste of time:

Going to observe experienced/senior teachers in your school
Something something learning styles
Think about what the behaviour is communicating
Make your lessons more fun
Think about what needs you aren't meeting

Even things which are more concrete like "meet them at the door"...yeah but HOW

Do I stop them all before they come in and do line-up? Do I let them in one at a time? In clumps? Where do I stand so I can see in and out? What kinds of thing do I say to them?

GAH

Too woolly:

Be firm
Stay calm
Follow the policy
Build relationships
Have clear expectations of what you want
Increase the pace of the lesson

I mean, sure, but HOW

Roughly once a week, someone on here asks for behaviour advice. 

Roughly once a week, there is a deluge of bad behaviour advice in response. Generally four categories:
1. So woolly as to be meaningless
2. A waste of time
3. Actively damaging
4. Impossible stuff

As ever, if you want to be treated like a grown up, to have your judgement respected and to have the freedom to make your own decisions about your professional advancement...APPLY

DMs open too :)

We do have policies, you need policies, and there are some areas where you can't really have much deviation (e.g. core curriculum choices), but as much as we can, we let people choose. 

>

A couple of my colleagues said to me they wanted to learn about coaching. That's fine, come sit in on some mentor meetings. Others have asked to join learning walks, or be part of cross-curricular conversations with other departments. All good, man. 

>

We also have control over our professional development. We have an excellent service in-house on improving T&L and other aspects of teaching, but individuals get a lot of choice over which avenues they want to pursue. 

>

As individual teachers, we also have some flexibility around how we deal with certain students. I might make suggestions and say "have you thought about trying x" but if they say "yes, but I think it would be better to do y" then that's ok too

>

Sure, when I said to my boss that I wanted to excise marking, he said "ok" and then gave me some pretty robust challenge. I went away, had a think, came back with a proposal and he was like "ok, go for it."

>

E.g., the science department doesn't mark students books and doesn't use group work. The maths department does a lot of group work. The English department mark books. We have the ability to decide.

>

This expresses itself in a number of areas. For example, in departments, we have autonomy to dictate our Teaching and Learning policy. We have whole-school prerequisites like Cold Call and giving students independent practice, but beyond that we have departmental autonomy. 

>

First, it's important to note that Autonomy doesn't mean "do what you like." Its etymology comes from "self-law" - it's about deciding the kind of teacher, professional and colleague you want to be and sticking to that like law. 

>

Ok, final thread is about our value of Autonomy.

We respect our colleagues. We respect their knowledge and their expertise. So our basic principle is also to trust their judgement and their ability to make decisions on their own. 

What does this look like?

In sum, I'm a head of department and work pretty hard, but I'm normally clocked off for the day by 5 and rarely work on the weekend (normally only in the twice yearly mock exam season). I also value *all of the work that I do* and know that my time isn't being wasted on nonsense>
does briefing for the whole of Y12, she sends me off. Take the gift of time and do something useful with it. >

Gift of Time: we know that time is the greatest gift, so if we can give it we do. This week, our whole-school meeting was cancelled because everyone was knackered and we can fulfil the content of the meeting in other ways. I'm a Y12 form tutor, and whenever the head of sixth >

Purpose: since I started two years ago, I think there have been like five things I've needed to do that I thought were actually not a good use of time. On each occasion I raised them as issues, and they were rectified if possible (some depended on systems outside our control) >

We also keep things curated. Each topic has one folder. Each folder has one booklet. You don't need to go sifting through zillions of folders and files to try and figure out what you are supposed to teach and what resources already exist for you to use. Waste of time. >

E.g. in the science dept, we have booklets, and if someone wants to do something else that's fine but they need to be better than the booklets. There is zero expectation that people make resources from scratch. Modify for your class, sure, but from scratch? Madness. >

Planning: no frequent lesson plans (1 a year for a formal obs, and even then it's more like "just explain to me what's in your head as you think about the lesson. Help me understand your lesson"). We also have a lot of centralised resources, and no stigma about that. >

What we try to instead is something like: "this student is on an 8 in maths, English, history and art, but a 5 in science. What's going on here? Why has this happened, and what can we do about it?"

It's a *much* better starting point for conversation and intervention. Anyway. >

E.g., in other schools I might be told "this student has a target of an 8, and in science they are on a 5. What are you doing about it?" and I'd be annoyed, because the target might be inappropriate. It isn't actually useful (see @MrARobbins and @bennewmark for more).

>
We also actually *use* the data, and we use it intelligently. Too often data is entered and then ignored. We use it to identify students who are "winnable." >

Data: other than year 11 and 13, we have two data drops a year, and that's it. We rigorously and scrupulously avoid double entry, give notice a long time in advance, plan the calendar to avoid pinch points etc. We don't do written reports. >

Marking: departments have the freedom to choose if they will mark, the nature of that marking and its frequency. In the science dept for example, we don't take books in, and if one of the team was doing comment based marking I would have a Strong Conversation with them. >

First and most obvious is cutting the nonsense. The three big areas according to the DfE are Data, Planning and Marking. So, one by one:

>

There's probably loads that I don't even notice. I'm quite confined to the science corridor, and don't get around as much as I'd like. To be honest, I've got used to them just being a constant presence.

>

They are also constantly communicating with each other. This means that they all have a good knowledge of all the issues across the school, and can deploy a much greater level of understanding when it comes to helping support you. Makes you feel like they *really* care. 

>

They're all on the walkabout channel too, so often even if they aren't on walkabout I've had an SLT member pop by a few minutes after a call to check everything is calm and settled and sorted (often the principal himself does this). 

>

They all have offices, but are often not in them. They don't shutter themselves up. I think this entire year other than with my direct line manager I've had like four conversations with an SLT member in their office. All the others have been outside or around the school. 

>

Everyone knows where and when to find them, and they are always happy to help and support. I've worked with SLT who made you feel like any problem you bring to them is beneath them. Ours don't. 

>

SLT are a presence at more social aspects of school too, they join things like HIIT club, yoga and staff choir (currently suspended). That's important too, makes them approachable. 

>

E.g. a colleague was struggling with some students who were consistently not doing homework, and the discussions after the lesson weren't going well. So a member of SLT swings by and helps out now. 

>

Lots of wandering through lessons, especially with new staff at the start of the year.

Always on hand during any line-ups like for assembly

We have "hot spots" too, so particular areas of the school that need support in particular lesson starts or ends

>

One member of SLT helps serve food, which is a really lovely thing and allows her to a) see loads of kids, b) see loads of staff (and be seen by staff) c) show the kitchen staff how much we value them and d) show the students how much we value the kitchen staff

>

I got a follow-up question to this which was "how do SLT become more visible?"

Some examples...

Our SLT:

Do duty every morning
Do late gate duty
Do duty every lunch
These are in the same spots each time, which makes them easy to find (don't underestimate this)

Has anyone read this? Read excerpts in the meeting the other day…
@Clive_Hill @Mallrat_uk https://t.co/bo4W8M8Ayx

We've all been in schools where leaders talk a good game but when push comes to shove, aren't there. Absent. Nada. Empty chairs. 

We're not that school, because we have chosen to not be that school, and because We Do What We Say We Do.

/end

PS, apply https://t.co/iDnFp0SKGs

In a meta sense, WDWWSWD when it comes to doing what we say we do too. Doing what we say we do is one of four whole-school priorities this year, that every member of staff, from the kitchen staff to the heads of department to the LSAs to SLT to the site team know off by heart. >
focused observations, video lesson feedback, behaviour CPD tracks etc etc. We *say* we support, so we *do* support. >

As leaders, we *say* we support, so we *must* support. Any request for support is met. We are in and out of lessons the *whole* time. We make ourselves available for supportive upskilling conversations, restorative conversations, centralised detentions, >
We are relentlessly honest about things like behaviour. Teachers are always believed and always supported. Leaders know that if they walk into a quiet room, it might be because they just walked in. >

E.g. our departmental t&l policy is a reflection of the things we actually do, not the things we wish we did, or we think a better teacher than us would do. we meet the policy. We then try new things throughout the year and if it works, we put it in the policy for next year. >

We go out of our way to *not* do this. We take a few things, we discuss how we are going to do them, and then we relentlessly focus on smashing those things out the park. If there's something we *want* to do, but can't yet, we don't do it, and we don't say we do do it. >

Schools are also completely fatigued by innovation. Some senior or middle leader goes to do an NPQsomething and before you know it there's a new whole school initiative around metacognition or student voice or whatever. There's a briefing. A training session. Nothing changes. >

On the ground, this often turns out to not be the case. Sometimes, leaders have no idea because they are cooped up in their office all day. Sometimes, leaders are outright lying. Most of the time leaders just don't realise what the reality is like on the ground. 

>

DWDWWSWD stands for Do We Do What We Say We Do?

All too often, schools and leaders talk a good game.

"Behaviour is consistently good across the school"

"All lessons start with a retrieval Do Now"

Don't forget that one of the main points of MWBs is just to get all the kids writing. There's nowhere to hide. So start nailing that as an objective, and once you have a good routine of everybody writing, then start stressing about data collection. >

Obviously, you need to pretend to look at all the others. So crane your neck a bit, say thank you to a couple of named students but don't stress out too much over it. Sampling like this is still better than verbal responses. >

More importantly though, remember that you don't need to see every response. One of the points of MWBs is getting data on understanding. So just look at the boards of your weaker students as a sample.

>

First you can read them whilst circulating, the second you set the task if you don't have behaviour issues you can go for a quick look round. Writing on a MWB is bigger and easier to see as you pass than book work >

A question about MWBs I often get even in normal times: how do you read every answer when it's more than a word or number?

Collapsing classes is on the agenda again. This is highly undesirable, but may be your least bad option. We had to do it last year, and here are some tips to make it more bearable and productive. https://t.co/C4JnifpgqR
I'm sure I'll think of more but my son just started crying so I will check back in later if I think of any others
If you aren't familiar with those terms, go here https://t.co/FiEHPzQLbA

your behaviour routines like 3:30:30 and Pastore's Perch are even more important here. There may be entire lessons where you don't circulate at all. That's fine, this is an imperfect situation so you are just trying to do the best you can.
I used a simple radio mic. it's weird at first, but everybody gets used to it and makes a big difference. it was like 40 quid. get IT team to sort it out for you.

behaviour: go hard, go early. most students will rise to the occasion once you have explained things to them, but if someone steps out of line jump on it immediately and come down hard on them. it is unacceptable to disturb that number of students.

entrance is really important. Have a seating plan, call out the students row by row from outside. have someone inside (SLT preferably) just put them into those seats. maintain that seating plan as much as possible, as it helps with routines and getting them started etc.
an extra pair of hands like an LSA or a technician can really help. if you can, get someone like this into the room.

get your weakest students right at the front. when you do mini-whiteboard work, pretend to look at everyone's but really just look at the ones at the front. the point is to get everyone writing or thinking, not to actually check each answer.

The QLA thing is a failure to appreciate this distinction. Going question by question is very useful at initial instruction, but not later on, when it's more useful to make inferences about, and tailor intervention to, wider understanding, which doesn't emerge from QLA.

Both types of "test" (or question) have their uses, but at different points. Literal tests are needed when students are first learning something. You need to see if they understand this one thing. But as knowledge builds over time, you need representational tests. https://t.co/Ib0TVLVEKS

@ejsearle @amymayforrester As ever, for more see here https://t.co/FiEHPzQLbA

@ejsearle @amymayforrester these techniques work with *anyone* who is struggling to maintain a presence in the classroom. it's a simple fact that being small, new to a school, inexperienced and female will often -though not always - give you a harder time in the classroom. >
@ejsearle @amymayforrester on their desk to show you are listening to them but don't take eyes off everybody else. >

@ejsearle @amymayforrester when circulating, do the crab walk to make sure your body is facing into the room at all times and you are turning your back on as few students as possible. then when you go to talk to a student, don't crouch down to them. stay standing upright, stay scanning the room, put a hand

@ejsearle @amymayforrester positioning is also crucial, make sure that the trainee uses Pastore's Perch as much as possible. Some of my teachers actually have a step that they stand on so they can see everyone. Again, but weird at first but really helps over the long term and kids get used to it >
@ejsearle @amymayforrester to the student at the back of the room, but not shouting, just talking, can make a difference. stuff like that. just ask the drama teacher. >

@ejsearle @amymayforrester If you aren't sure how to do this, go speak to your school's drama teacher (or music). They can also give you exercises to do which are awkward at first but can make a big difference to how you project your voice around the room. E.g. just imagining you are always talking

@ejsearle @amymayforrester Projection: crucial to use the "chest voice" rather than the "head voice". This is about where your "voice" comes from, and using the chest voice tends to be more commanding, direct and authoritative (it also strains you less)
